case_name: Bhaiyalal Shukla v. State of Madhya Pradesh

facts.text: Bhaiyalal Shukla filed six petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution challenging the levy of sales tax on building materials supplied by him in construction of buildings, roads and bridges for the years 1953-54 to 1958-59.

anchor.surface_text: These six petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution have been filed by one Bhaiyalal Shukla, who was doing business of companystruction of buildings, roads, bridges etc., as companytractor for the Public Works Department in Rewa Circle of the former Vindhya Pradesh State, number a part of the State of Madhya Pradesh. By these petitions, he challenges the levy of sales tax on building materials supplied by him in the companystruction of buildings, roads and bridges for the years, 1953-54 to 1958-59.

facts.text: Bhaiyalal Shukla was a contractor for the Public Works Department in Rewa Circle of the former Vindhya Pradesh State, now part of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: have been filed by one Bhaiyalal Shukla, who was doing business of companystruction of buildings, roads, bridges etc., as companytractor for the Public Works Department in Rewa Circle of the former Vindhya Pradesh State, number a part of the State of Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: For 1953-54, sales tax amounting to Rs. 1,840-5-0 was charged and paid by the petitioner, who seeks refund.

anchor.surface_text: For the first year in question, sales tax amounting to Rs. 1,840-5-0 has already been charged and paid. He seeks refund of this amount.

facts.text: For remaining years except the last two, assessment proceedings completed but amounts not paid.

anchor.surface_text: For the remaining years except the last two, proceedings for assessment have been companypleted, but the amounts have number been paid.

facts.text: For the last two years, proceedings for assessment of tax are pending.

anchor.surface_text: For the remaining two years, proceedings are pending for assessment of the tax.

facts.text: Respondents are State of Madhya Pradesh (substituted for Vindhya Pradesh) and officers connected with assessment and levy.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents in the case are the State of Madhya Pradesh, which stands substituted for the State of Vindhya Pradesh, and diverse officers companynected with the assessment and levy of the tax.

facts.text: Petitioner contends tax not leviable per State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley (1959 SCR 379) and Pandit Banarsidas v. State of MP (1959 SCR 427).

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the petitioner is that the tax is number leviable in view of the decisions of this Court in two cases reported in The State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley and Co.,  Madras  Ltd., 1959 S.C.R. 379 and Pandit Banarsidas v. The State of Madhya Pradesh 1959 S.C.R. 427.

facts.text: Respondents claim tax leviable per Mithan Lal v. State of Delhi (1959 SCR 445).

anchor.surface_text: The respondents, however, claim that the tax is leviable, because the case falls within the decision of this Court reported in Mithan Lal v. The State of Delhi 1959 S.C.R. 445.

facts.text: United State of Vindhya Pradesh formed by Rulers of Baghelkhand and Bundelkhand with Maharaja of Rewa as Rajpramukh.

anchor.surface_text: The United State of Vindhya Pradesh was formed by the Rulers of the States in Baghelkhand and Bundhelkand, who agreed to unite into a companymon State, with the Maharaja of Rewa as the Rajpramukh.

facts.text: Vindhya Pradesh Sales Tax Ordinance 2 of 1949 promulgated by Rajpramukh.

anchor.surface_text: The Rajpramukh in exercise of his powers drawn from the Covenant, promulgated the Vindhya Pradesh Sales Tax Ordinance 2 of 1949 for the levy of a tax on the sale of goods in Vindhya Pradesh.

facts.text: Vindhya Pradesh became Part B State then transferred to Part C by Constitution Amendment of First and Fourth Schedules Order, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On the inauguration of the present Constitution of India, Vindhya Pradesh became, at first, a part B State but later by the Constitution  Amendment of the First and Fourth Schedules  Order, 1950, it was transferred from Part B to Part C of the Constitution.

facts.text: Ordinance applied to whole Vindhya Pradesh from April 1, 1950 by Notification No. 7 of March 28, 1950 by Chief Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The Ordinance of the Rajpramukh was applied to the whole of Vindhya Pradesh with effect from April 1, 1950 by Notification No. 7 of March 28, 1950 by the Chief Commissioner, Vindhya Pradesh, acting under s. 1 2  of the Ordinance.

facts.text: Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947 extended to Vindhya Pradesh by Notification S.R.O. 6 dated 1950-12-29.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the power companyferred by the above section, the Central Government by Notification No. S.R.O. 6 dated December 29, 1950, extended to the State of Vindhya Pradesh the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947  21 of 1947  as in force for the time being in the State of Madhya Pradesh, subject to certain modifications necessitated by the application of the Act to this new area.

facts.text: Notification S.R.O. 6 added section repealing Vindhya Pradesh Sales Tax Ordinance 2 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: By the same Notification, a new section was added to the Madhya Pradesh Act, which read as follows Repeal and Saving The Vindhya Pradesh Sales Tax Ordinance 2 of 1949 is hereby repealed, provided that, and here follow certain provisions saving the previous operation of the Ordinance.

facts.text: Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act came into force in Vindhya Pradesh from 1951-04-01 by Notification No. 52/ECON dated 1951-03-20.

anchor.surface_text: On March 20, 1951, the Central Government issued Notification No. 52/ECON. in exercise of the powers companyferred by sub-s.  3  of s. 1 of the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947, as extended to the State of Vindhya Pradesh by Notification No. S.R.O. 6, ordering that from April 1, 1951 the extended Act would companye into force in the State of Vindhya Pradesh.

facts.text: In Delhi Laws Act case (1951 SCR 747), majority held s.2 of Part C States Laws Act 1950 intra vires except concluding sentence.

anchor.surface_text: On May 23, 1951, this Court rendered its judgment in In re the Delhi Laws Act 1912 1951 S.C.R. 747. It was held by majority by this Court that s. 2 of the Part C States  Laws  Act, 1950 was intra vires, except for the companycluding sentence...

facts.text: Government of Part C States Act 1951 (49 of 1951) passed on 1951-09-06.

anchor.surface_text: Parliament then passed the Government of Part C States Act, 1951  49 of 1951  on September 6, 1951.

facts.text: Part C States Miscellaneous Laws Repealing Act 1951 (66 of 1951) enacted on 1951-10-31, repealed VP Sales Tax Ordinance from 1950-12-29.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the decision of this Court in the Delhi Laws Act case 1951 S.C.R. 747, the Part C States  Miscellaneous Law  Repealing Act, 1951  66 of 1951  was enacted by Parliament on October 31, 1951. By s. 2 of that Act... the Vindhya Pradesh Sales Tax Ordinance, 1949  2 of 1949  was repealed from December 29, 1950.

facts.text: Vindhya Pradesh Laws Validating Act 1952 (6 of 1952) passed, deemed CP & Berar Sales Tax Act in force from 1951-04-01, came into force 1953-01-08.

anchor.surface_text: The Vindhya Pradesh Legislative Assembly... passed the Vindhya Pradesh Laws  Validating  Act, 1952  6 of 1952 . By that Act, which was to extend to the whole of Vindhya Pradesh and to companye into force on January 8, 1953, it was provided... Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947 as extended to Vindhya Pradesh... has been  and shall be deemed to be in force in Vindhya Pradesh from April 1, 1951.

facts.text: CP & Berar Sales Tax Act defined contract, goods, sale to include materials in building contracts, making them liable to sales tax.

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 of the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947, which was extended to Vindhya Pradesh, defined companytract to mean any agreement... and finally defined sale as including a transfer or property in goods made in the companyrse of the execution of a companytract. By these definitions, the materials used or supplied by a building companytractor... were made liable to sales tax...

facts.text: In Gannon Dunkerley case (1959 SCR 379), Supreme Court held states cannot tax sales of materials in building contracts under Entry 54.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Gannon Dunkerleys case 1959 S.C.R. 379 approved the latter view... It was pointed out that though in a popular sense there was a sale of the materials, there was numbere in the sense in which the expression sale of goods is used in the Indian Sale of Goods Act...

facts.text: In Pandit Banarsidas case (1959 SCR 427), held no tax if entire contract, yes if separate contracts.

anchor.surface_text: In Pandit Banarsi Dass case 1959 S.C.R. 427... it was held that if the parties entered into distinct and separate companytracts... then there was a sale... but that if the companytract was an entire one, the levy was without companypetence.

facts.text: In Mithan Lal case (1959 SCR 445), held Parliament's extension to Part C States valid despite state limitations.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents, therefore, seek to uphold the impugned provisions on the basis of the ruling of this Court in Mithan Lals case 1959 S.C.R. 445, where it was pointed out that whatever might be said of the State Legislatures operating under List II did number hold good in the case of Parliament...

facts.text: Court holds CP & Berar Sales Tax Act validly extended to VP by Parliament's authority, not affected by Gannon Dunkerley.

anchor.surface_text: The necessary result thus was that its operative part survived and the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947 was validly extended to Vindhya Pradesh, and was valid law as laid down in Mithanlals case 1959 S.C.R. 445. It did number suffer from the defects pointed out by the this Court in Gannon Dunkerleys case 1959 S.C.R. 379, as it was number extended or extended by the State Legislature.

facts.text: VP Laws Validating Act 1952 did not re-enact but declared existing extension valid from 1951-04-01.

anchor.surface_text: This declaration did number extend proprio vigore the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, but only declared that it must be deemed to be validly in force from April 1, 1951.

issues.text: whether the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947 can be said to have been extended for the first time by the Vindhya Pradesh Legislature in 1952 when it passed the Vindhya Pradesh Laws Validating Act, 1952 to the exclusion of the order contained in the Notification No. S.R.O. 6, or whether the Act continued to be in force in Vindhya Pradesh even before, and all that the Vindhya Pradesh Act did was to remove any doubts about its validity

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, to see whether the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947 can be said to have been extended for the first time by the Vindhya Pradesh Legislature in 1952 when it passed the Vindhya Pradesh Laws Validating Act, 1952 to the exclusion of the order contained in the Notification No. S.R.O. 6, or whether the Act continued to be in force in Vindhya Pradesh even before, and all that the Vindhya Pradesh Act did was to remove any doubts about its validity.

issues.text: whether the Notification S.R.O. No. 6 dated December 29, 1950 was invalid in its entirety because the portion repealing Ordinance 2 of 1949 was ultra vires per Delhi Laws Act case

anchor.surface_text: The contention on behalf of the petitioner is that the Notification dated December 29, 1950 was invalid in its latter part, as decided by this Court in the Delhi Laws Act case 1951 S.C.R. 747. That portion dealt with the repeal of Ordinance 2 of 1949, and if the Notification was invalid in that part, then the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, which was extended by the opening part, never came into force.

issues.text: whether the Part C States Miscellaneous Laws Repealing Act, 1951 validly repealed the Vindhya Pradesh Sales Tax Ordinance 2 of 1949 retrospectively from December 29, 1950, making room for the CP Berar Act

anchor.surface_text: Even if the Notification, S.R.O. No. 6, failed to repeal Ordinance 2 of 1949, Parliament by its own law effected that Ordinance in Vindhya Pradesh from December 29, 1950, and enacted that the Ordinance shall be deemed to be repealed from that day.

issues.text: whether the Vindhya Pradesh Laws Validating Act, 1952 re-enacted or freshly extended the CP Berar Sales Tax Act (thus invalid per Gannon Dunkerley) or merely declared its prior validity

anchor.surface_text: This declaration did not extend proprio vigore the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, but only declared that it must be deemed to be validly in force from April 1, 1951.

issues.text: whether the extension of CP Berar Act to VP by Parliament/Central Govt under Part C States Laws Act is valid despite Gannon Dunkerley defects, given Parliament's plenary powers over Part C States

anchor.surface_text: whatever might be said of the State Legislatures operating under List II did not hold good in the case of Parliament which derived its powers in relation to legislation in Part C States, not only from all the Lists but also from the residuary powers of taxation

anchor.surface_text: The respondents, therefore, seek to uphold the impugned provisions on the basis of the ruling of this Court in Mithan Lals case 1959 S.C.R. 445, where it was pointed out that whatever might be said of the State Legislatures operating under List II did not hold good in the case of Parliament which derived its powers in relation to legislation in Part C States, not only from all the Lists but also from the residuary powers of taxation

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed; tax imposed by Parliament itself via incorporation

arguments.claim: CP & Berar Sales Tax Act validly extended to VP by SRO 6 under Part C States Laws Act; not affected by Gannon defects

anchor.surface_text: The necessary result thus was that its operative part survived and the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947 was validly extended to Vindhya Pradesh, and was valid law as laid down in Mithanlals case 1959 S.C.R. 445. It did not suffer from the defects pointed out by this Court in Gannon Dunkerleys case 1959 S.C.R. 379, as it was not extended by the State Legislature.

arguments.claim: Even if SRO 6 repeal invalid per Delhi Laws, Part C Misc Repealing Act 66/1951 repealed Ordinance 2/1949 retrospectively from Dec 29 1950

anchor.surface_text: Even if the Notification, S.R.O. No. 6, failed to repeal Ordinance 2 of 1949, Parliament by its own law effected that Ordinance in Vindhya Pradesh from December 29, 1950, and enacted that the Ordinance shall be deemed to be repealed from that day.

arguments.claim: VP Laws Validating Act 1952 declaratory only; did not extend/re-enact CP Berar Act but deemed it in force from Apr 1 1951

anchor.surface_text: This declaration did not extend proprio vigore the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, but only declared that it must be deemed to be validly in force from April 1, 1951.

arguments.claim: S22 Govt Part C States Act 1951 prevents VP legislature from repugnancy to parliamentary extension

anchor.surface_text: To begin with, the powers of the Vindhya Pradesh Legislature were circumscribed by s. 22 of the Government of Part C States Act, 1951, quoted earlier. Under that section, the powers of the State Legislatures did not extend to making laws repugnant to any law made by Parliament.

arguments.claim: Different tax laws in MP regions post-reorg valid under Art 14; historical geographical classification upheld
Deepchand distinguished; repeal by Parliament removed unconstitutionality without re-enactment needed

holdings.text: The Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947 was validly extended to Vindhya Pradesh by Notification S.R.O. No. 6 and constitutes valid law as per Mithan Lal, unaffected by Gannon Dunkerley defects since not extended by State Legislature.

anchor.surface_text: The necessary result thus was that its operative part survived and the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947 was validly extended to Vindhya Pradesh, and was valid law as laid down in Mithanlals case 1959 S.C.R. 445. It did number suffer from the defects pointed out by the this Court in Gannon Dunkerleys case 1959 S.C.R. 379, as it was number extended or extended by the State Legislature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parliament/Central Govt extension under Part C States Laws Act carries plenary powers over Part C States, incorporating law as parliamentary despite List II limits applicable to states; follows Mithan Lal.

holdings.text: Even if Notification S.R.O. No. 6 failed to repeal VP Sales Tax Ordinance due to ultra vires concluding sentence per Delhi Laws Act, Parliament validly repealed it retrospectively from Dec 29, 1950 via Part C States Misc Repealing Act 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Even if the Notification, S.R.O. No. 6, failed to repeal Ordinance 2 of 1949, Parliament by its own law effected that Ordinance in Vindhya Pradesh from December 29, 1950, and enacted that the Ordinance shall be deemed to be repealed from that day.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parliament has plenary power to repeal retrospectively; cures defect in notification's repeal portion without affecting extension; Notification and Repealing Act concur.

holdings.text: Part C States Misc Laws Repealing Act 1951 validly repealed VP Ordinance 2/1949 from Dec 29, 1950, making room for CP Berar Act.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the decision of this Court in the Delhi Laws Act case 1951 S.C.R. 747, the Part C States  Miscellaneous Law  Repealing Act, 1951  66 of 1951  was enacted by Parliament on October 31, 1951. By s. 2 of that Act... the Vindhya Pradesh Sales Tax Ordinance, 1949  2 of 1949  was repealed from December 29, 1950.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct parliamentary enactment with retrospective effect; independent of prior notification.

holdings.text: VP Laws Validating Act 1952 did not freshly extend or re-enact CP Berar Act but declaratorily deemed it validly in force from Apr 1, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: This declaration did number extend proprio vigore the Central Provinces and Berar Sales Tax Act, but only declared that it must be deemed to be validly in force from April 1, 1951.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of preamble and s.2 as removal of doubts; s.7 repeals prior laws in force before enforcement date (Ordinance), not the extension itself; limited by s.22 Govt Part C Act preventing repugnancy to Parliament.

holdings.text: VP Laws Validating Act 1952 merely declaratory, confirming prior parliamentary extension's validity from Apr 1, 1951; did not invoke state competence limits of Gannon.

anchor.surface_text: The preamble of the Act shows that it was enacted to remove certain doubts which were entertained as to whether the extended Sales Tax Act become operative only from October 31, 1951 when Act 66 of 1951 was passed, or from an earlier date, viz., April 1, 1951

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act adds authority to prior extension without re-enacting; distinguishes extension from coming into force; s.7 targets pre-enforcement laws like Ordinance.

holdings.text: Deepchand v. UP distinguished; no re-enactment needed as repeal by Parliament removed unconstitutionality independently, validating prior extension without conflict.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Unlike Deepchand, extension did not depend on repeal for validity; repeal cured surplusage in notification; cites Willoughby approving no re-enactment if cause removed.

holdings.text: Different sales tax regimes on works contracts in MP regions post-reorganisation do not violate Art.14; historical/geographical classification valid.

anchor.surface_text: The laws in different portions of the new State of Madhya Pradesh were enacted by different Legislatures, and under s. 119 of the States Reorganisation Act, all laws in force are to companytinue until repealed or altered by the appropriate Legislature. holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-existing valid laws continue per s.119 States Reorg Act; differentiation from historical reasons upheld per Prithi Rajji and Gwalior Sugar precedents.

holdings.text: VP Legislature powers under Govt Part C States Act s.22 did not allow repugnant laws to parliamentary extensions.

anchor.surface_text: To begin with, the powers of the Vindhya Pradesh Legislature were circumscribed by s. 22 of the Government of Part C States Act, 1951, quoted earlier. Under that section, the powers of the State Legislatures did number extend to making laws repugnant to any law made by Parliament.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.22; Explanation includes extensions as parliamentary law.

holdings.text: Tax levy on building materials in works contracts under extended CP Berar Act valid in VP; petitions fail.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the petitioner is that the tax is number leviable in view of the decisions of this Court in two cases reported in The State of Madras v. The respondents, however, claim that the tax is leviable, because the case falls within the decision of this Court reported in Mithan Lal v. The State of Delhi 1959 S.C.R. 445.

We, therefore, reject this argument.
